hive_text_custom.text:
: Rachel, I thought we would
                      talk a little bit about items and their

, like how
                      long will you keep something? For example, like a
                      book or clothing, because yesterday I was talking
                      to my students and they were surprised when I
                      admitted that the shirt I was wearing, I had had
                      for over 10 years. Now, they're young and they
                      can't imagine that.

: No, that might be a
                      function of being young.

: Because their clothes of
                      10 years ago are obviously too small.

: Do you like to keep your
                      clothes a long time?

: If I really like them, I
                      might.

: I toss out clothes once
                      or twice a year. I'll

my wardrobe and throw out things
                      that are too small or have started to look shabby.
                      But there are other things that I just keep year
                      after year after year, probably things people
                      don't see as often like pajamas might last a
                      little longer.

: Some people advise that
                      if you haven't worn something for six months, you
                      should throw it out, but that seems to me to be
                      not logical, given that there are four seasons and
                      they last a year. If you haven't worn something
                      for a year, maybe you should consider throwing it
                      out. But yeah, definitely, at the start of the
                      season, not in the opposite season. You have to
                      think about the weather.

: Yeah. What about food? We
                      live in Japan. We're both teachers in Japan. One
                      thing I often wonder about is the sashimi and the
                      sushi, the raw fish. How long can you keep it
                      before you eat it? They say you're supposed to
                      have it that night, but I sometimes eat it the
                      next morning or even for lunch.

: With fish, as well as
                      other meats, I think it's very easy to tell,
                      because you can tell by the smell whether
                      something's good or not. I actually think that
                      rice is more dangerous.

: Yeah, because it will
                      grow bacteria. Because it's been warm, it will
                      grow bacteria easily at room temperature. The rice
                      is the part you need to be careful about.

: Oh. Well what about other
                      foods? Like are you somebody who's really strict
                      about the expiration date?

: I'm not. I think the
                      expiration date on most products
errs on the side of safety

.
                      And another thing is people confuse the best by
                      date with the expiring date.

: The best by date is just
                      about freshness, flavor. For example with spices
                      ...

: And that's the date they
                      put on the package in the store.

: That's often the date
                      that people go by.

: Yeah, sell by and best
                      by. For example spices might have a best by date.
                      After that, they might plump a little, they might
                      lose a little flavor, but they're not dangerous.

: You can still use them,
                      yeah.

: My rule is always three
                      days. So, I'll eat anything if it's within ...
                      except for meat, maybe, but anything if it's
                      within three days of the expiration date or the
                      sell-by date on the store's ...

: Oh, I think that matters
                      ... To me it makes an enormous difference what it
                      is. For example, moyashi, which is bean sprouts,
                      I'll eat them on the day or the day after, but not
                      after that. They start getting bad really quickly.
                      But, for example, a jar of pickles, that's going
                      to last much longer than the three days after.

: Right. I think the big
                      one, I guess, you're right about time, is dairy.
                      Milk is obvious, because milk you can smell. But
                      cheese ...

: But on the other hand,
                      it just turns into yogurt.

: Right, yes. So that's the
                      other one is yogurt. So yogurt, I'll see it in the
                      fridge and I'm like, "How long can I keep this?"
                      Like sometimes it'll be past the expiration date,
                      but it smells fine, it looks fine.

: Well, yogurt is soured
                      milk, so it's difficult to say at which point it
                      sours, because it's already sour.

: Yeah, and cheese too lasts
                      forever it seems like.

: Pretty much. You can see
                      the mold on cheese.

: Yeah. So what about if you
                      see bread and there's a little mold on the bread?

: Are you old school? Will
                      you cut around it?

: No. I used to and I used
                      to cut the mold off cheese, but having learned
                      more about visible mold is only a small amount of
                      it and parts of mold you can't see are branching
                      into the food.

: Yeah. So that makes it a
                      little

.
                      So, no I probably wouldn't eat bread that had any
                      kind of mold on it. And I'm dodgy about cheese to.
                      That's got the wrong sort of mold on it.

: There's the right sort
                      of mold like a blue cheese, and that's fine.

: Right. And I should
                      clarify here, neither of us are medical
                      professionals.

: We're just talking about
                      our own habits here, so ...

: What about juice? What
                      about juice? Like how long can you keep juice? Can
                      you smell when juice is bad?

: I don't usually buy
                      juice, so I don't really know.

: Yeah, I'd probably toss
                      juice because I'm not experienced enough with it,
                      obviously, to have

about it, so I'd probably
                      go by the date with that one.

: What's interesting is when
                      you see some foods that you think would last
                      forever, but actually they won't, they just have
                      an expiration date that's way in the future, like
                      canned goods.

: Sometimes it's surprising
                      when you're like, "Oh, there actually is an
                      expiration date on there."

: But it's way in the
                      future.

: It's way in the future,
                      as long as the can's not dented, I think ...

: ... is the rule for
                      that. Yeah.

hive_lesson_quiz.question: 1)  How long did he have his shirt?
2) How often does she toss out clothes?
4) If they see mold on bread, what do they do?
5) How do they check if juice is bad?

hive_text_custom.text: Let's talk about items and their
Shelf life is the amount of time an item is                          usable. Notice the following:

hive_vocab.examples: Canned food has a longer shelf life than                            fresh food.

hive_text_custom.text: When you toss something out, you throw it                          away. Notice the following:

hive_vocab.examples: Toss out that salad. It is five days old.

hive_text_custom.text: my wardrobe and throw out things.
When you go through something, you examine                          it carefully. Notice the following:

hive_vocab.examples: I went through my inbox and I didn't find                            your message.

hive_vocab.word: err on the side of safety

hive_text_custom.text: err                          on the side of safety
When you err on the side of safety, you are                          extra careful or cautious. Notice the                          following:

hive_vocab.examples: That looks old. I would err on the side of                            safety and not eat it.

hive_text_custom.text: So that makes it a little
When something is dodgy, it lacks in quality                          or trust. Notice the following:

hive_vocab.examples: This street looks dodgy. Let's avoid it.

hive_text_custom.text: When you make up your mind, you decide on                          something. Notice the following:

hive_vocab.examples: I made up my mind not to quit my job.

hive_text_custom.text: on what to eat for dinner.
